title: A jump in oil prices is creating trading opportunities in these investments
text:
An attack on Saudi Arabian oil fields has removed about 5% of global oil supplies. As a result, oil prices have jumped.

It sounds scary for oil and stock investors, but for the time being, the chart tells a different story. All investors, not just oil investors, ought to pay attention to this chart.

Chart

Please click here for an annotated chart of oil futures CLV19, -1.53%.

Note the following:

• From the chart, note the down-sloping trendline.

• Oil gapped open.

• Oil has, as of this writing, broken above the trendline.

• Note from the chart that oil has not touched the resistance level.

• Even before the attack on Saudi oil fields, oil was tracing higher lows, as shown on the chart.

What does it all mean?

The fact that oil did not break above the resistance shown on the chart indicates the following:

• President Trump would cushion the oil price increase by releasing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, if needed.

• Other countries also have oil reserves that may be used to cushion a price rise.

• Saudi Arabia has a substantial stockpile of oil that it can use to keep the market supplied with oil.

• Other OPEC countries and Russia can pump more oil.

• It is relatively easy to increase production of oil in the United States.

• In spite of sanctions against Iranian oil, Asian countries may end up buying more of it.

• The world economy is slowing. The latest data from China shows that industrial production is at its lowest point in 17 years.

• A slowing world economy uses less oil.

• Since the U.S. is self-sufficient in energy, there should not be much impact on the U.S. economy.

• Saudi Arabia is claiming that it will bring back about one-third of the production rather quickly.

Concerns

The situation should calm down without much of an impact on investors, unless scenarios similar to the following occur:

• Similar attacks on oil production not only in Saudi Arabia, but elsewhere in the Middle East, happen again and again.

• The U.S., along with its allies, attacks Iranian oil fields and installations.

• Iran attempts and succeeds in closing the Strait of Hormuz. The Strait of Hormuz is a choke point in oil shipments.

Investing and trading

The following are of interest to investors and traders:

• Oil ETFs exhibit tracking errors. Having said that, ETF USO, +12.15% is of significant interest. For very short-term trades, leveraged ETFs such as UWT, +34.39%, DWT, -39.75%, OILU, +34.54% and OILD, -39.67% are of interest.

• Regarding oil equities, ETFs XLE, +3.36%, XOP, +10.80% and OIH, +8.59% are of interest.

• Among large-cap oil stocks, Exxon Mobil XOM, +1.50%, Chevron CVX, +2.16% and Royal Dutch Shell RDS.B, +1.99% are of interest.

• Traders looking for larger movements may look at Comstock Resources CRK, +5.77%, Denbury Resources DNR, +27.87% and Whiting Petroleum WLL, +48.94%.

• Of significant interest are oil-service stocks such as Halliburton HAL, +10.95% and Schlumberger SLB, +5.30%.

• Cruise lines such as Carnival CCL, -3.22% and Royal Caribbean Cruises RCL, -0.78% may be negatively affected.

• Airlines such as United Airlines UAL, -2.84%, Delta Air Lines DAL, -1.57% and American Airlines AAL, -7.28% may also suffer in the short term.

• Refiners such as Valero Energy VLO, -3.67% may benefit.

• India and China may be adversely affected because they are crude importers. Indian ETFs of interest are EPI, -2.52% and INDA, -2.38%. Chinese ETFs of interest are ASHR, -1.45% and FXI, -1.05%.

• Russian ETF RSX, +1.82% may benefit.

Historically, such incidents tend to de-escalate and early moves in stocks and ETFs reverse in due course. This represents mostly trading opportunities and not necessarily long-term investing opportunities.
